quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 10 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 10.9: Equilibrium Relationship
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: The relationship between Gibbs Free Energy and the equilibrium constant K

questions.question: Which equation correctly relates the standard Gibbs free energy change ($\Delta G^{\circ}$) to the equilibrium constant ($K$)?
questions.explanation: This equation links thermodynamic stability to the extent of a reaction. Note the negative sign, which ensures that a spontaneous reaction (negative $\Delta G^{\circ}$) results in a large $K$.

questions.question: If a reaction has an equilibrium constant $K > 1$, what can be said about its standard free energy change ($\Delta G^{\circ}$)?
questions.explanation: When $K > 1$, the natural log ($\ln K$) is positive. Multiplying by $-RT$ makes the resulting $\Delta G^{\circ}$ negative, indicating a product-favored reaction.

questions.question: What is the value of the non-standard free energy change ($\Delta G$) when a system reaches chemical equilibrium?
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, there is no longer a net driving force for the reaction to proceed in either direction, so $\Delta G = 0$.

questions.question: Which constant is represented by 'R' in the equation $\Delta G^{\circ} = -RT \ln K$?
options: The ideal gas constant ($8.314\ J/mol\cdot K$)
questions.explanation: Since $\Delta G$ is measured in energy units (Joules), we use the gas constant $8.314\ J/mol\cdot K$.

questions.question: If $\Delta G^{\circ}$ is exactly zero, what is the value of the equilibrium constant $K$?
questions.explanation: If $0 = -RT \ln K$, then $\ln K$ must be 0. Since $e^{0} = 1$, the equilibrium constant must be 1.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a 'thermodynamically dead' system?
options: A system with a very high $\Delta H$.
questions.explanation: A system at equilibrium can no longer perform work because its free energy is at a minimum; hence it is described as thermodynamically dead.

questions.question: What happens to the position of equilibrium if $\Delta G^{\circ}$ becomes more negative?
options: The equilibrium shifts further toward the products.
The equilibrium shifts further toward the reactants.
questions.explanation: A more negative $\Delta G^{\circ}$ corresponds to a larger $K$, meaning the products are even more thermodynamically favored over the reactants.

questions.question: The relationship $\Delta G = \Delta G^{\circ} + RT \ln Q$ is used to calculate:
options: The free energy change under non-standard conditions.
The activation energy of a reaction.
questions.explanation: This equation allows us to find $\Delta G$ for any given concentrations or pressures by using the reaction quotient $Q$.

questions.question: Why does a reaction with a positive $\Delta G^{\circ}$ still produce a small amount of product?
options: Because $K$ is small but never truly zero.
Because the reaction is actually exothermic.
Because entropy always increases in the surroundings.
Because the catalyst forces the reaction to happen.
questions.explanation: Even if $\Delta G^{\circ}$ is positive, $K$ will be a small fraction (e.g., $10^{-5}$), meaning a tiny but measurable amount of product exists at equilibrium.

questions.question: How does an increase in temperature affect $K$ for an endothermic reaction ($\Delta H^{\circ} > 0$)?
options: $K$ increases as $\Delta G^{\circ}$ becomes more negative.
$K$ decreases as $\Delta G^{\circ}$ becomes more positive.
$K$ remains constant because $\Delta G^{\circ}$ is standard.
questions.explanation: For endothermic reactions, increasing $T$ makes the $-T\Delta S$ term more influential (if $\Delta S$ is positive) or simply drives the equilibrium toward products per Le Chatelier's Principle, increasing $K$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand the deep link between thermodynamics and equilibrium.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Remember the difference between standard $\Delta G^{\circ}$ and non-standard $\Delta G$.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Review the natural log relationship between $G$ and $K$.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the condition $\Delta G = 0$ at equilibrium.
